entry.title: Combined summary - Fee drop
entry.summary: Bitcoin developer Peter Todd expressed concerns in 2014 about the addition of a low-fee transaction feature to the Bitcoin software, which could lead to DDoS attacks. He suggested adding a memory-limited mempool prior to release as a mitigation strategy and argued that releasing software with known and obvious DoS attack vulnerabilities was irresponsible. The community is looking to add similar measures to prevent low-risk DDoS exploits and address issues related to dust and fee management. Despite these challenges, Bitcoin remains a good medium for microtransactions compared to other alternatives.One potential risk associated with the implementation of lower transaction fees is the possibility of a DDoS exploit. Bitcoin developer Peter Todd expressed concerns in 2014 about the potential for large groups of low-fee transactions to be created and double-spent with higher fee transactions to consume network bandwidth. He suggested adding a memory-limited mempool prior to release to prevent this type of attack.In response to the concern raised about the discrepancy between MIN_RELAY and the expected minimum fee needed for a transaction to be included in a block, several solutions have been suggested. One possible solution is to align mempool selection with the expected block inclusion to optimize resource allocation. This means that miners would prioritize higher fee transactions based on max block size or orphan rate projections. Another solution is to eject a random transaction from the mempool that paid less fees than the incoming transaction, while considering how ejection would work with chains of unconfirmed transactions.The recent fee drop in cryptocurrency trading has been criticized for creating new vulnerabilities, but some experts argue that this is not the case. The reduction in fees simply puts them back to dollar terms as they were a few months ago. Therefore, the cost of an attack would be the same as before. In an email thread, Todd raised concerns about the potential for a low-risk DDoS exploit with the implementation of a fee drop. Troy Benjegerdes suggested including the change and asked for more information on what the DOS attack would look like. Finally, he commented on the advantage of Bitcoin being that people can learn from its mistakes and that it is not a one-size-fits-all fiat.The context highlights the importance of careful consideration and analysis before implementing any changes to mitigate potential issues. Mike Hearn discusses the possibilities of lowering transaction fees on the Bitcoin network and acknowledges the challenges involved in making changes to the network. The discussion also highlights the need for more DoS resistance, which requires significant time and resources spent on code audits and resource scheduling. Releasing software with known and obvious DoS attack vulnerabilities that didn't exist in the previous version would be irresponsible on multiple levels.Despite the challenges related to dust and fee management, Bitcoin remains a good medium for microtransactions compared to other alternatives. The writer suggests that large groups of low-fee transactions can be created and then cheaply double-spent with higher fee transactions to consume network bandwidth, and releasing software with known and obvious DoS attack vulnerabilities that didn't exist in the previous version is irresponsible. Overall, the community must continue to work together to address these concerns and ensure the long-term stability and security of the Bitcoin network.
